dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quadrangle of Army buildings is quiet and deserted. A broken-down taxi drives in at one corner and slowly makes way around the quadrangle. SUPERIMPOSED over shot is the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi pulls up across the street from camera. A soldie gets out, pulls two heavily loaded barracks bags after hi He pays the driver, hoists the bags to his back, moves to camera. The taxi drives away slowly. The soldier walks to steps leading to a low building. He is PREWITT (called "P for short), 22 years old, well-built, good-looking. He we an enlisted man's uniform and on the sleeves are marks wh chevrons have been removed. He pauses, looks up over the door. CAMERA PANS UP to sign which reads: ORDERLY ROOM - COMPANY, 219TH REGIMENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small thin soldier in an undershirt and fatigue pants b out of the screen door and into shot. He is wielding a fr broom. This is PRIVATE ANGELO MAGGIO. He is violent and f and sour and friendly. He sees Prewitt's legs but not his face, speaks as he sweeps a cloud of dust off the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine way to pass the time. Good for the mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Maggio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio turns and stares at Prew, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I transferred out of Fort Shatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio notices the marks on the sleeves where the stripes have been removed. Prew follows his glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You quit the Bugle Corps...? 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew nods. Maggio jerks his head toward the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To here...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what the orders say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made a bad mistake. This outfit they can give back to Custer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew smiles slightly, starts toward door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain ain't in yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew puts down his barracks bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles for first time) Maybe we borrow some money from a twenty per cent man and take a real trip to town some night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew walks slowly down the raised porch alongside the str He takes the mouthpiece of a bugle from his pocket, jiggl it idly, a habit of his. He comes to the Dayroom, glances through the screen door, goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dayroom has a pool table, ping-pong table, a radio, e Moth-eaten, upholstered chairs line both walls. The place empty as Prew enters. He looks around casually, sees the table in an alcove. He moves over to it, puts the bugle mouthpiece in his pocket, picks a cue from the rack on th wall. He switches on the light, chalks the cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The triangle of balls is already racked on the table. Pre addresses the cue ball, shoots and breaks the rack solidl He watches the balls hurry around the table. 3.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN'S VOICE, (O. S.)
dialogues.text: What're you think you're doing!? Why ain't you out in the field with the Compny? What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice is brawling, brash, vigorous. Prew turns slowly CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS to INCLUDE FIRST SERGEANT MILTON WARD almost at Prew's elbow. He is thirty-four, big and powerf has a neatly-trimmed moustache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prewitt. Transfer from Shafter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I heard about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard about you, too, Warden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, put up that cue and come along. This here's a rifle outfit, Prewitt. You ain't suppose to enjoy yourself before sundown. The Man's very particlar about little things like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden goes out of the Dayroom. Prew puts up the cue and follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Prew and Warden walk along the porch, Warden a few pac ahead. They go into the Orderly Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Prew and Warden enter. Maggio is sweeping the room. MAZZIOLI, a bespectacled, intellectual-looking Private Fi Class, is at the clerk's desk, opening it, taking out pap etc. Prew sits on a bench as Warden goes over to Mazzioli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mazzioli! Grant went to the hospital yesterday. Did you make up his sick record? Did you make a note for the morning report?! You're the Compny Clerk. The lousy Sickbook is your job! 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those medics didn't get the Sickbook back till late yesterday -- I'll tend to it right now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I already done it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio has swept his way over to Prew. He stops sweeping stares at the other man as if still incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you the beat bugler they got over at Shatter. You probly the best on this whole Rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In b.g., Warden has turned from Mazzioli and is looking a Prew. Prew looks back coolly, answers Maggio thoughtfully

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio wags his head, bends over to pick up wastepaper basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, friend, I feel for you. But from my position I can't quite reach you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten-sh-HUT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prewitt, Mazzioli and Maggio spring to attention. The scr door bangs and CAPTAIN DANA HOLMES enters shot. He wears cavalry boots and spurs. He is about forty, unsure of himself, therefore always too certain with his men. He no pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease. Good morning, men. Anything special this morning, Sergeant Warden? I've only a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New man here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Bring him in. 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes goes into his office. Warden jerks his thumb towar the door. Prewitt goes into the office. Warden follows hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes is seated at his desk as Prewitt and Warden enter. placard on it reads: CAPTAIN HOLMES. A smaller desk nearb has a placard' reading: 1ST SERGEANT WARDEN. Warden seats himself at this desk. On the walls are framed photographs prizefighters as well as one of a large golden trophy. On Holmes' desk is a small framed photograph of a very attractive blonde woman. Prewitt comes to attention in fr of Holmes' desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, Private Robert E. Lee Prewitt reporting to the Compny Commander as ordered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease. (takes papers out of drawer, glances through

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sent your service record over... Twenty-two years of age... born in Kentucky... enlisted first at Fort Myer, Virginia... Bugle Corps... re-enlisted for overseas duty... Fort Shafter... First Bugler...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prewitt, I always make it a policy to talk to my new men. It's important for an officer and his men to understand each other. Now I have a fine smooth-running outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes cannot see Warden who is grinning at Prewitt with unholy glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty of room for advancement for a man who knows how to soldier. But he's got to show me he's got it on the ball. I don't know what you've been used to in the Bugle Corps, but in my outfit we run it by the book. What kind of trouble were you in over there? 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What made you transfer out, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a personal matter, air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies Prew for a moment, sees Warden on the edge of chair, watching hawk-like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something you wanted to ask, Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Me? Whv, yes, air. You had Corpral's stripes in the Bugle Corps, Prewitt. You took a bust to buck Private to transfer to an Infantry Compny. Why? Because you like to hike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dint have no trouble if that's what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or was it just because you couldn't stand to bugle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a personal matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's up to the Compny Commander's discretion to decide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks straight at Warden) All right. I was First Bugler at Shafter for two years. The topkick had a friend who transferred in from the states. Next day he made him First Bugler over me. 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you asked out on account of that!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I just ain't sensible... But that's the reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His feelings were hurt! Kids they send us now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden swings his chair around, absorbs himself in work a his desk as if the Prew situation is too absurd to concer himself with. Holmes speaks blandly, winningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a mighty sour Company Bugler here... but I suppose you wouldn't want that job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we'll get your stripes back for you, maybe an extra one for good measure. You know why you were sent over here when you requested transfer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pulled a few strings. I'm the Regimental Boxing Coach, Prewitt. I saw your fight with Connors in the Bowl year before last. With any luck you should have won it. I thought for a while, in the second round, you were going to knock him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Regiment got beaten last year in the finals, as you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I mean to win this year. And I will. All I've needed was a top middleweight. (waves at pictures) Next year I'll hang your picture up there with the others, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, air. But I quit fighting.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES.
dialogues.text: Quit fighting? When? What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just stopped, sir... After -- Maybe you heard about what happened...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean that fallow you hurt -- the one that went blind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew's lips are drawn tight. He nods almost imperceptibly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this shot Maggio can be seen in b.g. through door Orderly Room. He pretends to be sweeping, but stops now a then to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's too bad about that. I can understand how you feel. But those things happen in this game. A man has got to accept that possibility when he fights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I decided I would quit, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But on the other hand, look at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: it this way. What if all fighters felt like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you have us disband our fighting program because one man got hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. I dint say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might as well say stop war because one man got killed. Our fighting program is the best morale builder we have off here away from home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it disbanded, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't see why any man should fight unless he wants to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks to me like you're trying to acquire a reputation as a lone wolf, Prewitt. You should know that in the Army it's not the individual that counts. If a man wants to get ahead he has certain responsibilities to fulfill that go beyond the regulations. It might look as though I were a free agent, but I'm not. Nobody is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes waits hopefully for a moment, then realizes Prew i not going to respond further. He stands. Prew snaps to attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you'll change your mind. In the meantime just don't make any mistakes in my outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go into town. Is there anything else for me today, Sergeant? 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up papers) Yea, sir! The Compny Pond Report's got to be made out. It's due

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make it out. Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up more papers) No, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, whatever it is, you fix it. If there's anything that has to go in this afternoon, sign my name. I won't be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out, crossing Warden's desk and knocking a wire basket filled with papers on the floor. In a moment, the sound of the screen door slamming is heard. Warden picks the papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd strangle on his own spit if I weren't here to swab out his throat for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. I'll show you the Supply Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden goes out to Orderly Room, Prew following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Prew and Warden enter and walk through. Maggio bobs hi head approvingly at Prew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they come out of the Orderly Room. Prew hoists his barracks bags to his shoulders, balancing them delicately CAMERA TRUCKS with him and Warden as they walk down the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (one of his unexpected

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what you did just now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you turned down Dynanite Holmes' boxing squad? You put your head in a noose. Things are soft for a boxer in his Compny. Otherwise, you better know how to soljer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can soljer with any man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't the Bugle Corps -- this is straight duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take my chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A convertible, top down, drives by and pulls up outside t Orderly Room. KAREN HOLMES, a tall, lean blonde woman, ge out. Her skirt hikes up a little as she goes up the stair the Orderly Room. Warden and Prew stop walking and watch Karen stops, glances at Warden momentarily, then goes int the Orderly Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when is this place gettin to be the Royal Hawaiian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife. Captain Holmes'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They resume walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll fight, Prewitt. You'll fight because Captain Holmes got a bee in his hat he needs a winnin team to make Mayor. And if you don't do it for him you'll do it for me. I only been in this outfit eight months myself but I learned one thing. My job is to keep him happy. The more he's happy the less he bothers me and the better I run his Compny. So we know where we stand, don't we, kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where I stand. I don't believe that's the only way a man can get along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man's got to make up his own mind and go his own way. It he don't, he's nothin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe back in the days of the pioneers a man could go his own way. But not in our time, kid. Today you got to play ball. You got to divide it all by two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have reached a Dutch door, top half open. A sign ove reads: SUPPLY ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPPLY SERGEANT LEVA is eating a candy bar with one hand leisurely typing up a form with the other. He is a foolis looking man, about thirty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lava! Can't I once walk by this Supply Room and find you workin with both hands!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comes up to door) I can't do no better on what you people pay me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw some supplies for this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's G Compny barracks over there. Get rid of your bags and come back here, and Leva'll find you a cart to lug your stuff over in. Save you makin four five trips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised, pleased) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just hate to see energy wasted. Any kind. Besides, you'll be needin yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew walks off, toting the barracks bags. The bang of the Orderly Room door is heard and Lava and Warden look in th direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she walks along porch toward them. She is at a considerable distance. Karen is about thirty. She wears a 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sweater and skirt. She is aware the men are studying her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching Karen. Leva leans over the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her and them sweaters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she continues toward them. As much as a man can make o she is probably not wearing a brassiere. Warden's and Lav voices, loud at first, get softer and softer the nearer K gets to camera. At end of the shot, as she is only a few yards away, they are practically whispering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Army women... They're cold, they got no more warmth than a diamond. There's no pleasure in them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but this one knows the score... Like I been tellin you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, not around here. But I was back at Fort Bliss with Holmes. When they was married only a year or two. I heard plenty about the lady then. Plenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, never me. But a lot of them. I know some of the Use she played 'around with, don't tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't tellin you. You're tellin me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen stops, a few paces from camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lava watches, listens avidly but discreetly in b.g. Durin the dialogue, Karen seems irritated by Warden, who looks her coolly, appraisingly, physically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for my husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Holmes just went in town, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Of course, He was to have left some things for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That he was to have purchased. Do you know anything about them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, I don't. Is there anythin I can do for you?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN.
dialogues.text: No, thanks, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes slight move to go, pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been telling me quite a bit about you lately. My husband. He says you're very efficient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it that makes you so efficient, Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't help it if I was born smart, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen laughs suddenly, loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love that. Well, good-bye, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen turns and walks back up the porch toward her car. Warden and Leva watch her. When she is out of earshot Lev speaks. 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But man, she sure is one, ain't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT 22 Karen, in a negligee, is seated at a dress table, brushing her hair -- steadily, gracefully, enjoyin the sensual pleasure of it. Karen is a woman of moods and tempers, spontaneous, quick to impulse. A car is heard pulling up in the driveway, the motor stopping. Karen's b strokes become faster, rougher. The front door is heard opening and Holmes' voice calling, "Karen." She does not answer. Holmes enters. He seems to have had a few drinks. Through the following, Karen continues brushing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I'm so late. And about dinner, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I got tied up with General Slater. Bumped into him at the Officers' Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? What did the General have to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Success, he said. Success in war, success in peacetime... And not a word about my promotion... There are times I think the Old Man's just waiting to ship me down... (slumps into chair) I've had a bad day all around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: started right off this morning... trouble with a new man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd spend less time buttering Generals and more time with your Company, maybe you'd get that promotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Company takes care of itself. Or my Topkick takes care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went over there this morning looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had some business to attend to in town. During the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the way you look I gather your business wasn't too successful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana. Give me credit for a few brains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many, times do I have to tell you I haven't any other women before you'll believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen laughs sharply, loudly, then stops suddenly as she looks at herself in the mirror, sees the repugnance in he face. She puts down the hairbrush, picks up a long comb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it were so, don't you think I'd admit it? The way things are between us now? What right have you to always be accusing me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both tense now. Holmes is out of the chair and pacing. Karen combs her hair spasmodically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That again. How long will it be, I wonder, before I'm allowed to live that down? After eight years, how many times do I have to tell you It Was An Accident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes it all right, I suppose!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. I know what it's done to you, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I hate to talk about it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times do I have to tell you I'm sorry, about that? How many times that I had no way of knowing -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his hands on her shoulders. Karen shakes away, ri faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a way of knowing, Dana. I want to go to bed. Please get out of my bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes looks at her sullenly, then exits to adjoining roo closing the door behind him. There is a moment of silence then a sharp snap as Karen breaks the comb in two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is fairly well filled with soldiers. The click o pool balls is heard over shot. Warden is reading a newspaper.. A column heading, conspicuous in shot, reads: JAPS ADVANCE IN CHINA. Warden drops the paper on his lap, looks toward pool table, squinting thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio, Prew and CHIEF CHOATE, a Corporal, are playing po Choate is a full Choctaw Indian, a man of great bulk and tolerance. He speaks in a tremendously deep bass voice. T 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: table on one side is surrounded by the prizefighters of G Company. They are IRE GALOVITCH, an ape-like, bent-kneed weighing about two twenty, with a widow's peak almost to eyebrows; BALDY DHOM, chunky and tough, his head as bald an orange; TURP THORNHILL, a stringy, chinless Mississipi HENDERSON, a tall, hard Texan; CHAMP WILSON, wiry and goo looking. They are all Sergeants except Wilson, who is a Corporal. The men have been heckling Prew and are watchin with cold belligerence. Choate, bending over his cue, sho and misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coldern a Idaho winter tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew shoots, makes a brilliant shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, what I would not give to have this character in the corner poolroom in my home town: I'd dress him up on overhalls and a straw hat and put a grass in his teeth, and I would make a whole mint of ghelt off him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Choate laughs deeply. Prew sizes up a new shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd of won last year if we had a good middleweight. You box as good as you used to over at Shatter we're a cinch this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew doesn't respond. He bends over his cue again.

dialogues.text: You'd like that. You could get me a year in the Stockade for that one, couldn't you? 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: closing around a heavy mug in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden looking at Prew's hand. Warden's grin broadens wit something more than sarcasm. He is 'impressed and pleased Prew's honest anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't throw it, Prewitt. It might break on my head. And that would cost you one thin dime next Payday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden deliberately turns his back and walks off. Prew lo after him. CAMERA MOVES IN to FEATURE his hand on the mug grasps it tighter, then lets it fall back into the soapy water,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is blowing the bugle, sounding Pay Call. The rays of a blinding sun flash on its shiny surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bugle is heard over shot. A line of spruced-up men stretches through the mess hall. A blanket is spread over table and behind it sits Holmes, flanked by Warden and Mazzioli. In front of Holmes is a pile of greenbacks and cigar box filled with silver. He is paying out the man at head of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and just see you don't drink all this up in one place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man smiles, appreciating the whimsy, salutes, moves o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prewitt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew, next in line, steps up to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert E. Lee, RA 345071.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is crisp, sharp, expressionless. He holds out his hand for fingernail inspection. 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes looks them over, then up at the perfect knot in hi tie. He stares at Prew as if trying to fathom him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you given any thought to the boxing team recently, Prewitt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel the same way, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes' hands clench. He seems about to fly into a rage w he senses a motion at his side. He turns to see Warden looking straight at him. Warden's face has the same meaningfully expressionless look as Prew's. Holmes wilts before it, turns to Mazzioli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this man's pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from Payroll) Private Prewitt, thirty dollars base pay. Deductions-laundry, insurance, PX checks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES IN to CLOSE SHOT of Holmes# hands laying mon out on blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Total due twelve dollars thirty cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Payday night. A gay, noisy jamboree. Soldiers, mostly in civilian clothes, and uniformed sailors swarm down the street. Taxi drivers arguing with their fares as they pul at bars. Filipinos padding in twos and threes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio and Prew, dressed in slacks and Aloha shirts, stan front of what looks like a renovated residence. They give evidence of having already accomplished a little substant drinking. The sound of loud piano playing is heard from within. A sign over the door reads: NEW CONGRESS CLUB - S DRINKS - DANCING - RECREATION - MEMBERS ONLY. The door op 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and MRS. KIPFER stands at the threshold. She is a sophisticated-looking woman with upswept hair, wears an evening gown with a corsage of orchids. The piano music, louder with the opening of the door, continues through al the following. The pianist is hammering out "I Don't Want Set The World On Fire" (or a similar hit of 1941).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greetings, Mrs. Kipfer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, it's Angelo Maggio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He barges past her through the door. Mrs. Kipfer frowns a follows him. Prew shrugs and goes in after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Prew enters behind Mrs. Kipfer. The vestibule has an o South feeling of mustiness and respectability. Maggio is handing some bills to ANNETTE, a young, brash-looking gir who sits behind a reception desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... so there y'are. Dues all paid up. Who ya got playin the piana -- a hippo?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIPPER
dialogues.text: Angelo, I don't believe I've met your friend. And you know how I hate to find you boys in this condition...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. You see. Any time women see a soldier, think he's drunk. Why? You know why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he is.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIPPER
dialogues.text: Heavy drinking simply doesn't mix with the entertainment business. Every respectable place must consider its future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kipfer, ma'am, I give you my solemn word your future will be safe with us. 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio nods vigorously in agreement, then pushes through heavy curtains which separate the vestibule from the room beyond. Mrs. Kipfer looks after him a little unhappily.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIPPER
dialogues.text: Angelo is one of my favorites. Annette, dear, take care of this gentleman, will you, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kipfer exits through the curtains. Annette takes a c from file, picks up pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be eight bucks, Babyface. Four for initiation fee, four for April dues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what do I get for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rattling it off) Members are entitled to all privileges of the club which includes dancing, snack bar, soft drink bar, and gentlemanly relaxation with the opposite gender so long as they are gentlemen and no hard liquor is permitted. (takes a breath) Got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew grins, digs in his pocket for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several rooms branch off from this main one. There are ab a dozen soldiers in civilian clothes -- and about a dozen hostesses. Several couples are dancing. The man at the pi is banging away, his music clashing cacophonically with a jukebox record from an adjoining room. CAMERA PANS as Mrs Kipfer moves to and fro encouraging the men to enjoy themselves. The New Congress is a sort of primitive U.S.O place of well-worn merriment. It is not a house of prostitution but the girls look available for goosing... but one we see at the end of the PAN. She sits alone on a couch. This is LORENE. There is an innocent, child-like l about her. Her hair is done demurely in a circular roll l on her neck. She is about twenty-four. She is reading a 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: magazine, untouched by the din around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pounding the piano as if he is trying to knock the keys o He has an enormous head and a hogshead chest. He resemble Porky Pig. His dead eyes look like two beads of caviar sp far apart on a great white plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio is attempting some serious dancing with SANDRA, a tall girl. Fatso's furious tempo and tune keep drowning t langorous tango coming from the jukebox. Maggio keeps switching his style as he tries to get out of the range o the piano but cannot. He is very annoyed. He and Sandra d out of shot, as Prew and Annette enter from the vestibule CAMERA PANS them to a trio of girls on a couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Girls, here's some new poison. This is Billy and Jean and Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls smile, ad-lib hellos. Prew is looking over the girls' heads at someone in rear of room out of shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if she senses someone is staring at her, she looks up the magazine, smiles serenely across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she reacts sourly to Prew's reaction to Lorene. He see transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me the Princess is your style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annette takes his arm, moves him toward two quite good- looking girls talking to a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet Suzanne and Roxanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls greet him heartily but Prew is looking back ove his shoulder at Lorene. Annette plucks his sleeve with haughty disdain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much as I adore your company, you must allow me to tear myself away. I see a few friends at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also I can see I will be of no use to you much. 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks off. The other girls resume talking to the sold Prew continues to gaze across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: smiling back. Her head tilts up slowly as if someone is coming toward her. Prew comes into shot and stands before her, tongue-tied. She pats the couch. Her voice is low- pitched, poised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Lorene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enchanted by the name) Lorene...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you in here before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew gestures with the membership card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dint know about this place till now. A friend of mine brought me. We're stationed at Schofield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Somehow I didn't think you were a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bridles a bit) Well, I am. And I'm in for the whole ride. I'm a thirty-year man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose it's different when a fellow is going to make a career of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ain't anythin wrong with a soljer that ain't wrong with everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorene smiles her fatal smile at Prew's seriousness. 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you just the same. I liked you the minute I saw Annette bringing you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too. I mean when I came in. I saw you over here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a commotion across the room. A group of man and girls are surrounding the piano. Fatso has stopped playin and a shouting argument is going on between him and Maggi Prew looks over, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll play loud as I want, ya little Wop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A babble of voices drowns out Maggio's reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wait right here for me, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where two men are holding Fatso and three girls are restraining Maggio. The others are amused by the quarrel, Fatso and Maggio are deadly serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mess with me, Fatstuff, I'll pull you apart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the kind of character I eat for breakfast, ya little --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio breaks away from the girls and rushes toward Patso Prew, stepping through the group, grabs him. Mrs. Kipfer bustles into the melee.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIPFER
dialogues.text: Now, you gentlemen know I will not have any of this sort of thing. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, you Wop, he says to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Mussolini here tryin to tell me what way to play the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, my ear drums fit to bust already with that noise!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KIPFER
dialogues.text: You man can simply leave if you're not going to behave yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Angelo, come on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Ony my friends can call me Wop --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where Prew hauls Maggio away from the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (has been watching) You know who that guy is, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I know who he is. Whadda I care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fatso Judson. Sergeant of the Guard at the Post Stockade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: settling down at the piano again. He glances over in direction of Maggio with a mean smile. Then he starts to hammer the keys viciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the music starts, Maggio stiffens, turns as if to go b Prew holds tight, to his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm tellin you, leave him be. Nets danger. I seen him nearly murder a guy once. He likes it. 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra comes over, disengages Prew's arm from Maggio's, p her own around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, bully boy, now you won the war, let's dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to quiet down) First I got to calm my nerves. Come on with me to a phone booth or some thin. (slaps himself on belly) Where I will unveil this fifth of whisky I got under this loose flowing sports shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Sandra start off toward an adjoining room. Prew smiles, turns back toward Lorene. The smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: PREW'S POV
dialogues.text: Lorene is looking at another soldier, on the couch beside her, with her rapt, innocent expression.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT PREW
dialogues.text: as he crosses room to Lorene, hurt and disappointed. CAME HOLDS on MEDIUM SHOT as he comes up to her and the soldie talkative man named BILL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you go along as fast as forty miles per through that surf and your balance has got to be letter perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I thought you were gonna wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up, smiles) Bill here was telling me about surfboarding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down and just listen. He describes it thrillingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew sits down, disgruntled. Bill notes his expression. 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know anything about surfboarding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nothing. Not a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be stationed inland then. I'm at DeRussey so I get lots of chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? But then we got mountains. You know anything about mountain climbing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little bit. Are you a mountain climber?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You know anything about flying an airplane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorene is frowning now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had a few lessons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't fly either. What do you know about deep sea diving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to move into another room, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. The air in here seems to have gotten very smelly, hasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I noticed that, too --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, fellow --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we go, then? 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She and Bill rise. She smiles tremulously at him as she t his arm and they start off. She throws a severe glance ov her shoulder at Prew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He settles lower in the couch, the picture of frustration hopelessness. He pulls a cigarette from his pocket and li it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen sits on the bench, her ankles crosses primly, very at ease. There is Payday activity here also; amorous strolling couples; men in ones and twos looking for picku Several unattached men pass Karen, ogle her. She is about get up and leave when Warden comes into shot, stands over her. His civilian suit is neat and well-cut. Both are strained, awkward, antagonistic. Now that the step has be taken they are not at all sure it was a clever one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, hello. I didn't think you were coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? I'm not late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I guess you're not. But then I came a little early. I must have been overanxious. You weren't overanxious though, were you? You got here right on the dot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'd of been early too only I stopped to get a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You certainly chose a savory spot for our meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you rather it'd been the cocktail lounge of the Royal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I've had five chances to be picked up in the last few minutes. 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits beside her on the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's par for the course around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't care for it. I never went in much for back-alley loving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably think I'm a tramp, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think I'd think that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to be gallant, Sergeant. If you think this is a mistake, come right out and say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, what started all this, anyway? Why'm I shakin inside like a school kid out with teacher! Where'd I come up with a yen for of all things the Compny Commander's wife! And her actin like Lady Astor's horse all because I only got here on time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden's burst shatters the tension. Karen breaks into laughter. After a moment, Warden joins in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other hand, I've got a bathing suit under my dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny. I got one in a U-Drive-It parked around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand. They rise and walk away, backs to came They merge with the other couples in the little park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fatso's piano music o.s. Prew is slumped on the couch. He stubs out the cigarette, which is almost burnt down. He s someone coming toward him, slowly raises his eyes. Lorene comes into shot, looks down at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the surfboard rider?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a terrible way to have acted. What you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a funny one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you dames want? To take the heart out of a man and tie it up in barbed wire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry because she really

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, look here, what do you think Mrs. Kipfer pays us for? We're hired to be nice to all the boys. They're all alike. Is it so important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's important. Maybe we seem all alike but none of us is ever all alike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'm sorry about before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touched by his outburst) That piano is about to drive me out of my mind. Let's go up to Mrs. Kipfer's suite and sit there. She lets us use it sometimes... for somebody special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you mad? 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you're still mad I'd just rather we called the whole thing off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes his arm) You certainly are a funny one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk away from camera, merging with the others in-th room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sweeping over camera, spray flying.

dialogues.speaker: BEACH
dialogues.text: A tiny beach set among rocks. The pale sand glows in the moonlight. Warden, in a bathing suit, is lighting a fire about ten yards from the water's edge. Karen is just step out of her dress; her bathing suit is underneath. A coupl GI blankets near the fire. Her teeth are beginning to cha in the chill of the night air; she raises her arms to the longingly, happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope the ocean's ice cold. I hope I freeze in a solid chunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sudden, intense laugh) Just so long's you melt afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the way you laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands, moves to her. She laughs, turns and runs into water. He runs after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: near shore, as Karen dives into it. Warden follows her. T wave washes over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ANGLED so we see only back of the divan. We hear s chuckles from Prew and Lorene o.s., then silence for seve moments. CAMERA MOVES as we hear a few more low, intimate laughs, then Prew and Lorene are disclosed on the couch, their heads close together as if they have just kissed pleasantly but not passionately. Mrs. Kipfer's living roo on the order of the vestibule; it, too, has a faded laven feeling. A door leading to another room is half open in b A door leading to a hall is closed. Prew's arm is around Lorene's shoulder; he is very relaxed, regards her with something like wonder. Lorene is mellower, too, making no effort now to be "the Princess." She speaks as if resumin conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I enlisted, too. I came out here on my own. To get away from my home town. In Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a boy friend. I was a waitress. He was from the richest family in town. He just married the girl suitable for his position. After three years of going around with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pretty story, isn't it? Maybe they could make a movie of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did. Ten thousand of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorene smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I left and went to Seattle, as a waitress. And I met a girl just back from Hawaii. She said she'd made a lot of money working for Mrs. Kipfer. I caught the first boat. I've been here a year and two months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like it much? 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't like it. But I don't mind it. Anyway, I won't be here forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Sure not. I mean, why should you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have it all figured out. In another year I'll be back home, with a pile of bills big enough to choke a steer. And then I will be all set for life --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sound at the door and they turn towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it opens slowly and a disembodied arm pokes through, i hand gripping the neck of a whisky bottle. After a moment Maggio's head follows the arm through the door. He is grinning like an amateur conspirator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dint hear no sounds of combat. So I figgered maybe you'd like a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Maggio comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or otherwise old Sandra would of drank it all by herself. She's a fine girl. But she drinks like a fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are glasses on a cupboard near the divan. Maggio se three of them up, starts to pour whisky into them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks. I never drink much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggio stops short of the third glass. He takes a big gul from the first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it' a a weakness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grant you that. 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't like weakness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't like weakness. (rises, takes a drink) But I like to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes back to the divan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With you it's not a weakness. With you it's more like a virtue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds like a very profound remark. Maybe that's why I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snuggles to Prew) Well, it's so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! What you gonna do, marry this guy? Way you grinnin at him you look like his wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get outa here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up bottle) Okay. Back to old long-legged Sandra. I love 'em tall. Acres and acres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out, closing door behind him. Suddenly the door o again and Maggio pops back in. He puts the whisky bottle table next to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy yourself, pizon. You need it more than me. You be back with The Treatment tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pops out again, the door closing after him. Prew's gai dims with the reference to The Treatment. Lorene sees thi Prew rises, goes to whisky bottle. 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was nice before. The way you snuggled up. In front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he mean, The Treatment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew doesn't answer. He pours a drink, gulps it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the guys puttin me over the jumps because I won't fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fight?

dialogues.text: Over at Port Shafter... I used to fight... Middleweight. I was pretty good. I used to work out with Dixie Wells. He was a light-heavy, but he was fast... And good. He loved boxing. And we neither of us wore headgear, anyway. I was set flat on my feet when I caught Dixie wide with this no more than ordinary solid cross. Dixie just happened to be standing solid, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

The only thing was that he was blind... (rises, paces) I went up to the hospital to see him. Twice. Then I couldn't go back. We got to talking about fighting the second time. And Dixie cried... dialogues.text: All what story?

dialogues.text: You're getting to sound so much like a typical male. So you just sweat it out like a typical male.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd been married to Captain Dana E. Holmes two years. Only he was a First Lieutenant then. Back at Fort Bliss. We lived right on a little lake where we could fish and swim and be alone, our 'dream cottage'... I'm sure you must be able to picture it. It was off on a back road, four miles from the highway. Two miles from a neighbor and a telephone.... (pauses, then rushes on) I hadn't been married long when I knew my husband was stepping out on me. But -- you get used to that. Your mother tells you that it's life, that i t happens to a lot of women. Of course, she doesn't tell you until after it happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: reacting with fury toward Holmes, compassion for Karen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, by that time, you're pregnant. And at least you've something else to hope for. I think I was almost happy that night the pains began. Even though they were weeks too early, a whole month too early. I remember Dana was putting on that dapper silk gabardine uniform he used to wear. He was going to an officer's 'seminar.' He was kidding me about false labor. I didn't think it was humorous. I told him to get home early, to bring the doctor with him. He smiled tenderly and told me about the psychic reactions of women to pregnancy. But never fear, he'd be back early. And maybe he would have... if the 'seminar' hadn't been with the hat-check girl in one of the night clubs. 59.

They even took my appendix out, too. They threw that in free. It was all fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, of course, one more thing no more children. Do you know what that means? You're not a woman. You're not anything. You're a gutted shell... Sure, I went out with some of the men after that. A few months of it. I'd been made dirty and I wanted to be clean. You can see that, can't you?... Anyway, I got my revenge on Dana. I kept on living with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: She said it's over -- time to go

dialogues.text: It'll work out...

dialogues.text: It can't go on like this much longer, Milt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.text: If there were only a way! Your lovin husband'd probly give you the divorce. But even if he didn't know what for, he'd never let me transfer.

dialogues.text: You've got to become an officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure made a thorough study of it.

dialogues.text: Then I could divorce Dana and follow you and marry you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An officer! I've always hated officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fine, intelligent point of view. Suppose I said I've always hated Sergeants. That would make a lot of sense, wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits, thinks it over unhappily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, suppose I did it. -- And don't think it's a cinch -- the exams are tough. Then you'd be getting your divorce here while I'm in the States. We'd be apart maybe six months! We'll probly be in the war by then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be certain of that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it down on your calendar. On October twenty-third, 1941, Milt Warden told you we'd be in the war in less than a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just don't want the responsibility. You're probably not even in love with me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy! I wish I wasn't in love with you. Maybe could enjoy life again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's happened to you -- you were honest at first --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first! You were tough and solid as a rock -- and now you're a whining crybaby --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so they were married and lived unhappily ever after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are silent for several moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been so miserable in my life as I have since I met you.

dialogues.text: I wouldn't trade a minute of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither would I.

dialogues.text: as he listens. A look of mingled longing and satisfaction

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: listening, his face also betraying emotions normally concealed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office lit only by a light over his desk. He is worki late, a sheaf of papers spread out before him. He listens the bugle call, moved, sorrowful. He snaps off the light, listens in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lying on his back in his bunk, arms clasped behind his he He listens, his gnarled face the picture of the old soldi He breathes heavily as if he is hearing his own requiem a epitaph.

dialogues.text: There are eight or nine men here now, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a choked kinship on all the faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More men are propped on their elbows, their heads turned toward the Bugler. The dim figure of Treadwell can be see at a window now.  TREADWELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost inaudible whisper) ... I told you it was Prewitt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: continuing the Taps. There are tears in his eyes now.

dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.text: A half dozen men are sitting on the steps, listening, amo them Stark and Wilson. Stark shakes his head sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: listening now on the porch alongside the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several groups of two and three scattered about. They are standing in no particular places, as if they have been walking and stopped suddenly. They are all looking toward Bugler. 124.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Taps repeat is drawing to a close. He is lying on side, turned toward the Bugler, a look of serenity, of pe on his face. His eyes close as he falls asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Prew lowers the bugle slowly and lets the megaphone rest its swivel. He withdraws the mouthpiece, puts it in his pocket. He hands the bugle to Clark. Clark looks at the instrument as if it has become hallowed. Prew walks off i the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT.
