dialogues.text: TRACKING SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES along street, passing a lone pedestrian. It MOVES TOWARD the sign NEW CONGRESS CLUB, HOLDS beside an window through which is heard the sound of harsh piano playing; the pounding style and lack of shading are clear Fatso Judson's. CAMERA PANS AND INCLUDES Prew, leaning against the building. He is watching the entrance to the patiently. There is relentless hatred on his face. The mu stops. Prew does not move.   DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearty male laughter from within. The door opens and Fats and a couple of sailors cane out. They are about to start down the street.  PREW'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Fatso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fatso looks around in direction of voice. CAMERA PANS, DISCLOSES Prew, still leaning against the building. Fatso squints, not recognizing him. 125.    FATSO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me?  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Fatso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fatso takes a couple of steps toward Prew, squints again.  FATSO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like that nickname. You want to see me about somethin?  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Let's step around the corner here where we can talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew's voice is so toneless as to be ominous.  FATSO (GRINS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Good night, gents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sailors go off. Fatso walks into the darkness of an a next to the building. Prew follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just enough light from the street lamp to illuminate abou ten feet into the alley.  FATSO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. You sore about somethin?  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just don't like the way you play the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fatso throws back his head and laughs loudly.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Maggio?  FATSO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little Wop? The one who bust out of the Stockade? Sure. He was a real tough monkey. But crazy, see?  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You killed him.  FATSO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I? If I did, he ask for it. 126.    PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear they're gonna court martial you, Fatso. But before the Army gets you, I want a piece of you myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the snick of a blade snapping open as Fatso pull knife. He moves toward Prew, who steps swiftly to one sid  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kinds thought you'd try that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the same sound as Prew pulls a knife from his pocket, snaps it open, holds it out flat in his hand, sho it to Fatso.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This here's the one you pulled on Maggio once. Reconize it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fatso darts at Prew, knife raised. Prew moves back, but F is on him and they both roll to one side along the buildi The movement throws them deep into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two figures feint and dart. There is the occasional silver flash of the knives as light hits them. The men go deeper into the shadows, are all but lost to view. There startled, pained cry. Then one of the figures falls to hi knees and starts to crawl toward camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the figure comes directly to camera, REVEALING the anguished face of Fatso. It slowly turns, is upside down the frame.  MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fatso is on his back, his stomach gushing bloods his eyes already glazing. Prew staggers into the light now. His le side has two vicious cuts; he is bleeding badly. He stare down at Fatso, who manages a small, reproving voice.  FATSO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've killed me. Why'd you want to kill me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew backs away from Fatso, turns, staggers down the alle away from camera.  WIPE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew comes toward camera, laboriously struggling up the r His side is hemorrhaging steadily, his shirt and trousers blood-soaked. He stops close to camera. He wads his handkerchief, sticks it inside his shirt near the knife wound. He smiles wearily, crookedly.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbles to himself) Gonna have an awful bad scar there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lights a cigarette, his fingers shaking. The flame fro the match illuminates his left wrist. There is a deep sca it. It seems to fascinate Prew as he stares at it, rubs h fingers across it.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... scars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, moves on up the road; CAMERA MOVES CLOSE behind him, as if overhearing his thoughts which come over on so track.

dialogues.speaker: PREW'S VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: ... got that one fallin off the barn back home... gashed it on a spike... Dad laughed... Dead now... Uncle John+s dead, too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew moves away from camera out of shot.  WIPE TO:

dialogues.speaker: SHOT ANOTHER SECTION OF THE ROAD
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS Prew, as he keeps in shadows, moves slowly the cliff. He is in much pain now. His hand rubs across h face; his fingers linger on his forehead near his eye.

dialogues.speaker: PREW'S VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: ... that cut over the eye... in the ring at Myer... wouldn't let `em stop it... knocked the guy out... sixth round...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA LOSES Prew again as he stumbles into shadows.  WIPE TO:

dialogues.speaker: SHOT SITE OF PREVIOUS PREW-ALMA SCENE
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS Prew, who is now fighting hard to keep his feet. His hand is pressed tight to his side.

dialogues.speaker: PREW'S VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: ... ten stitch gash in the hip... workin in the gym attic... fell through the skylight... where was that?... so many scars... so many years... where they all gone to anyway...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves on around bend in road out of shot.  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio is blaring the "Hut Sut Song." Alma is crocheti Gorgette is reading. CAMERA SHOOTS across them to the fro door. The doorknob moves slowly, the door opens. Prew fal into the room and pitches to the floor.  ALMA PREW --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rushes to him, bends over him. Gorgette runs to the radio, turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face agonized as she leans over Prew.  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes himself up on one elbow, seems pleased by her stricken expression. He manages a smile.  PREW (WEAKLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry... Ain't gonna die. They savin me for better things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gorgette kneels into shot. Prew's smile becomes silly as turns his head to her. 129.    PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... just came up to borrow a good book.  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American flag, the General's flag and the Division fl are the only colorful elements in a rather severe office. Colonel Williams is reading from a typed report.  COLONEL WILLIAMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --- In addition to inefficiency in administering his command and neglect of duty, Captain Holmes has been guilty of indefensible cruelty to the aforesaid Private Prewitt. This extended to instigating and encouraging wholly unauthorized and discreditable tactics to force the soldier to join the inter-regiment boxing team. These findings are the result of personal investigation by the Inspector General and are corroborated by numerous members of G Company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Williams puts his report on the General's desk. Holmes' face reflects a weary resignation as if underneat has really expected something like this for a long time. makes no move to speak. The General is angry clear throug  GENERAL SLATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for your reply to this.  HOLMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't any, sir... The charges -- are true.  GENERAL SLATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, the first thing I ever learned in the Army was that an officer takes care of his men. It seems to be the first thing you forgot. It's monstrous to think of anybody like you in command of troops. And believe me, you won't be for long. My only regret is that we have to keep you in uniform until a court martial is concluded. (MORE)
GENERAL SLATER(cont'd) In the meantime, of course, I'm relieving you of your present duties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates the meeting is over. Holmes rises, is about leave, pauses.  HOLMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there were any way to avoid a court martial, sir. Any way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General frowns, is unresponsive. Holmes looks to Colo Williams helplessly.  COLONEL WILLIAMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is one alternative, General... if you're so disposed. A resignation for the good of the service under AR 600-275.  GENERAL SLATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks a moment) I'll give you a chance you don't deserve, Holmes. Write a letter of resignation and have it on my desk this afternoon. I'll consider accepting it. Only because as far as I'm concerned, the quicker you're out of the Army the better for everybody. Especially the Army.  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He confronts her, waving a sheet of stationery. His voice strangled, almost hysterical.  HOLMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --- that's right, it's a letter of resignations I'm through! I've already been relieved! So you can begin packing. We're sailing for the States next week!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head, not wanting to believe; she takes th letter out of his hand, starts to read it. She stops afte sentence or two. Her hand falls to her side. Holmes sits the bed heavily. The bluster bleeds out of him. He shakes head, emotionally bewildered. For perhaps the first time his life he is nakedly honest. 131.    HOLMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where has it gone, Karen? What happened to it? The gay, cheerful life we were going to have, you and I...? What happened to me...? The proud, dashing officer was going to be. The leader of men?... I've known all along how the men felt about me. They despised me... What's happened? I don't remember losing anything... Where has it all gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: reacting; she is surprised, a little afraid of her own emotion. The outcry, so lost, so despairing, moves her. S is sorry for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen -- you're coming back with me, aren't you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trembling, Karen puts the letter on the dressing table. Abruptly, she runs out of the room.  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FEATURING placard reading LIEUTENANT ROSS. We hear Ross' first few words over this, then CAMERA PULLS BACK to MEDI SHOT. Ross is forceful, clean-cut, gives the impression o toughness but fairness. As he talks he takes down the photographs of prize fighters and prize fighting from the wall. Watching and listening are Sergeants Dhom, Thornhil Henderson, Leva, Stark and Karelsen and Corporal Wilson. is such a complete switch from Holmes that the men are al unnerved by him. But a definite respect is reflected in t expressions. Warden, beside his desk, shares this.  ROSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I don't intend to have a sloppy outfit. I don't intend to have a goldbrick outfit. I don't intend to have a soft soap outfit. I've called you noncoms in because you're the backbone of any Company. (MORE)
ROSS(CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From now on you'll have to prove you're entitled to have those stripes here. And not in the boxing ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bands the pictures to Leva.  ROSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get rid of these, Sergeant.  LEVA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  ROSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I have to say. If you've any questions, speak up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody speaks.  ROSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men troop out, passing camera. As last man leaves, CA IS ON Warden. He is looking at Ross with considerable approval, even admiration. He resumes a more normal expression as Ross turns toward him.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One non-com was missing, sir. Sergeant Galovitch.  ROSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Private Galovitch is in the kitchen.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kitchen?  ROSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As of now, he's an assistant cook. I busted him. On a blanket charge of inefficiency. What are you grinning at?  WARDEN (GRINNING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the Company Commander made a wise decision, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Warden goes to his desk, answers. 133.    WARDEN (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compny G, First Sergeant Warden speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen's voice is heard on the phone; we cannot understand what she is saying, but a flood of words pours through. W Ross looking on, Warden is embarrassed.  WARDEN (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... Yes, I know... (glances over toward Ross) Yes, the - uh - parcel has already arrived... Yes... What?... (GRIM NOW)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, we'll have to talk about it soon. Right away. I - I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross perceives Warden's distress. He starts toward the do Warden nods gratefully. Ross smiles, leaves the room.  WARDEN (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lissen, I'll get away somehow, tonight. I'll meet you in Kuhio Park. At eight... Right....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts down the receiver. He stares at the desk. Then he slowly pulls out the top drawer. The Officers Application Blank is lying on top of a pile of other papers. He takes out, looks at it somberly. CAMERA MOVES IN to an INSERT o the Application. We see Warden's answers to sex, age, rac etc. CAMERA MOVES DOWN the page to the place for the signature of the applicant. It is unsigned.  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In b.g. Warden, in uniform, and Karen are sitting on the bench as in their first meeting in the park. We cannot he what they are saying at first. CAMERA MOVES IN past a few pedestrians and HOLDS on a MEDIUM SHOT. There is a defeat tired look about them, as if they have been talking for a long time to no avail.  KAREN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I guess I felt it that night I asked you to become an officer. When you didn't say yes right away. (MORE)
KAREN(CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I knew deep down you wouldn't do it. But -- (a hint of tears) It seemed such a simple plan for us...  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to -- I tried -- but I couldn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs his hand through his hair. He seems to be groping inside himself for some way to explain.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lissen -- there's a kid in our outfit named Prewitt... Robert E. Lee Prewitt... He came in from the States about a year ago. I thought he was a fresh punk at first... until I got to know him a little. He's AWOL right now -- probly in some kind of real trouble -- he ain't the kind to go AWOL otherwise. Anyway, I keep remembering somethin he said to me the first day he came in. He said a man has got to go his own way... if he don't, he's nothin... I'm an Enlisted Man. I'm a First Sergeant. Milt Warden. Once I cross that line and tried to be an officer, I'm somebody I don't know. A stranger. And a man has got to be what he is...  KAREN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that's the trouble with Dana... He's always tried to be something he isn't. Poor Dana... I don't think he ever needed me until now. (shaken herself out of it) Well, here we are saying goodbye. And talking about two other people.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not saying good-bye -- we'll figger out a way for you to stay HERE --  KAREN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back with him, Milt. There's something in being needed. It isn't love. But it's something. 135.    WARDEN (DESPERATELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lissen, two people who love each other just don't stop loving each other! Nothin and nobody is goin to break us up l 1111 transfer out somehow and get back to the States. Maybe it'll take a little time but I'll do it!  KAREN (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds like Milt Warden, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends toward her to kiss her. She presses him back.  KAREN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Milt. I don't want to kiss you any more. I just want to remember you. And you to remember me.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it down. Put it down that on December 6th, 1941, Milton Anthony Warden told you he'd remember you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK, PASSES a few pedestrians, Warden and K remaining in b.g. of shot. They begin to talk again, quie undemonstratively. We are too far away now to hear what t are saying.  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma is reading a newspaper in b.g. Prew is disheveled an slovenly, needs a shave badly. His face is lined with pai He is drunk from several days of steady drinking, stone drunk, as if in a trance. He wears crumpled civilian clot He is at a table laboriously writing out the Re-enlistmen Blues. He finishes writing a stanza and sings softly.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slep in the park that Sunday Seen all the folks gain to church Your belly feel so empty When you're left in the lurch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma looks up from the paper. 136.    ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is -- they're putting it on an inside page already. (READS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `... still no clue in the fatal stabbing of Staff Sergeant James R. Judson...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew, who has stopped singing but not turned his head, resumes the song.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dog soljers don't own pews Re-enlistment Blues...  ALMA (ANNOYED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear me? Are you listening or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew nods blankly. He rises slowly and walks across the r toward Alma. But his eyes are fixed on a whisky bottle on table beside her. He moves stiffly, favoring his side, hi face contorted. He picks up the bottle, pours himself a drink.  ALMA (COLDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to set a new world's record?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles faintly, holds the glass high.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... To the memory of Robert E. Lee Prewitt, Holder of the New World's Record...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know what you plan to do.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plan to do? When?  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any time. Now. Tomorrow. Next week.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lessee... (counts on fingers) (MORE)
PREW(CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... One... two... three... four... Four days I'm AWOL, ain't I? (picks up paper, looks at DATE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... this is December sixth, ain't it...?  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-tirade, half-wail) It's December sixth and you're so drunk you're wall-eyed. And all you've done since you fell in here is drink and drink and drink and try to remember that old song of yours. And I want to know what you're going to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew looks at her, hurt. He moves back to his table, mumbling.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... might ship out on a tramp and go to Mexico and be a cowboy...  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, be sensible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew sits at the table again, continues to mumble.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'm goin back to the Compny... soon's my side heals... Goin back under my own power... Goin into the Ordrly Room 'n' say hello, Warden, Private Prewitt reportin...  ALMA (BREAKING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Prew! Prew! Why did you have to do it? Why did you have to kill that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew shakes his head sadly as if he doesn't know the answ He picks up the paper he has been writing on, sings softl testing the last couple of lines affectionately.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recruitin crews give me the blues Old Re-enlistment Blues...  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.text: FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FEATURES clock on wall reading 7:52. About half th Company is at breakfast. There is considerable laughter a horseplay. Near the kitchen a dozen men are in the chow l  MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FEATURING Warden at the NCO table. He rises, carries his plate with him towards the chow line. A sudden, deep-tone earthquake-like blast shudders through the room. The cups the tables rattle. Warden stops, cocks his head. The men eating, look at each other.  ANDERSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the room) Must be dynamitin down to Wheeler Field.  CHOATE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them engineers mighty ambitious Sunday mornin before eight o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men resume eating. Warden moves a couple of steps tow the chow line when the second blast hits. It is much heav and fuller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has a hunch about this now. He reaches out to put his plate down, holding it very carefully in both hands. Howe he doesn't bother to see if there is anything under it. T plate falls and crashes on the floor a fraction of a seco before the third groundswell of blast shakes the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man sprints toward the mess hall, yelling to right and at the top of his lungs. As he approaches camera we see i Mazzioli.  MAZZIOLI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Japs're bombing Wheeler Field! It's the Japs! They're bombing Wheeler Field! The Japs! It's the Japs! I saw the red circles on the wings!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roar of the plane over shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure of Mazzioli gets closer and closer as the plan 139.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: dives toward him, machine guns spitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Jap plane flashes by close above him. The stones i the pavement pop up. Mazzioli flops on the street. The pl zooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the men rush out. In the front ranks are Warden, Karel Stark and Choate, Choate carries his half-filled plate in hand, a mug of coffee in the other. The men stretch their necks, following the plane. Then they look back up the street, CAMERA PANNING. Far in b.g, a column of black mushrooming to the sky. Warden dashes to Mazzioli. CAMERA MOVES IN to a CLOSE SHOT as Warden bends over him, hoists to a sitting position. He is extremely gentle. Mazzioli's knee is laid open and is bleeding freely. Warden whips ou handkerchief and starts to apply a tourniquet.  MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the men continue to crane at the sky. A few pick metal links from the Jap bullets.  NAIR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say! This'll make me a good souvenir! A bullet from a Jap plane!  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't jawbone! This is for record. Theme real bullets that guy was usin. Get inside -- all of ya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden gets Mazzioli to his feet, turns to first man in g surrounding them. It is Anderson.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help him over to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson starts Mazzioli down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of planes are diving toward the street.  WARDEN'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: GET INSIDE
dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men rush for cover, all except Choate who is left alo in shot. He takes a big bite of his sausage and eggs, has downs a swig of coffee. Then he throws the plate and cup the street and dives for cover as the terrifyingly loud n of the Jap planes indicates they are directly overhead. 140.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are pouring in from the Company street, all shout at once. Warden pushes his way through them and jumps up the pool table. His big voice booms.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right, you men! Quiet down! Quiet down! It's only a war. Ain't you ever been in a war before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men begin to quiet down, look to Warden respectfully. Through the scene the heavy earth shudders are felt and h as bombs hit in the far distance. Also the sound of the strafing planes.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna organize a fire umbrella defense. I want the non- coms to get BARs and ammunition from the Supply Room and get up on the roof. Henderson, you're in charge of the loading detail. Get movin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The non-coms push out the door.  TREADWELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what about me? I been waitin all my life to git to shoot a BAR at somethin!  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. It's your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Treadwell hurries after the non-coms.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of you guys - the CQ will unlock the rifle racks. Every man get his rifle and go to his bunk and stay there. And I mean stay there! I'm making each squad leader responsible to keep his men inside. If you have to use a rifle butt to do it, that's okay, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are shouts of protest. The men are over the first s now and beginning to get angry, anxious for action. 141.    WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me! This ain't no maneuvers. You go runnin around outside you'll get your ears shot off. You want to be heroes, you'll get plenty chances later. You'll probly have Japs in your laps before night.  SOLDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if they bomb us?  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear a bomb comin, you're free to take off for the brush. But don't worry -- the Japs'll probly drop all their bombs on Pearl Harbor and Hickam. They ain't gonna waste `em on us. So let's can the chatter. We're wastin time. Squad leaders, get `em upstairs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squad leaders begin to herd their men out. Warden jumps o the pool table. Stark and Karelsen come up to him.  STARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you want me to do, First? I got a hangover, but I can still --  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stick in the kitchen and make a big pot of coffee. No -- make a barrel of coffee.  KARELSEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I could get one of them Japs with a machine gun, Milt. We'll put the tripod over a chimney. And hold her down by the legs.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile at each other affectionately, then push into t crowd leaving the Day Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The non-coma are arguing violently with Leva at the door the Supply Room. Jap planes are loud overhead. 142.    LEVA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. I can't issue any live ammunition without a signed order from an officer.  HENDERSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there ain't no officers yet, you jerk! Lieutenant Ross lives off the post.  LEVA (FOLDS ARMS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry fellows. Lieutenant Ross give me them orders himself. No signed order, no ammo. And that's all they are to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden hurries up to the group.  DHOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't let us have no ammo, Top!  CHOATE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hats got it locked up. An the keys in his pocket.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme them keys!  LEVA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, Top. I got to obey my orders. No live ammo without a SIGNED --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They flatten against the wall as a Jap plane roars buildi high down the street, machine guns flaring. After it pass they rush back to Lava,  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? You blind? You see them planes --?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lava puts his hand in his pocket protectively, shakes his head.  LEVA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't gonna do it, Top. I --  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Chief, bust the door down. (TO LEVA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the hell out of the way! 143.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Choate, Henderson and Dhom back up for a run at the door. Leva moves in front of the door.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Bust it down. He'll get out of the way.  LEVA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember I warned you. I did my best.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll see you get a medal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden dashes up the porch steps as Choate, Henderson and Dhom launch themselves at the door. Leva steps aside. The door rattles ponderously, then flies open. The three battering rams careen into the Supply Room. The men stand by cheer and rush in after them. Leva shakes his head gri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are sitting on their bunks, unhappily, holding th rifles. Others who have slept through breakfast are dress hastily. Warden rushes into the room. The men immediately bark ad-libbed questions at him:  SOLDIERS (AD LIB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the deal, First? Why can't we go up on the roof? Where's the ammo, Top? Are we soljers -- or Boy Scouts?  WARN (PITILESSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start rollin full field packs! We may have to move out of here. Squad leaders, get `em packin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In b.g. Henderson and others are going up the porch stair the roof. They tote BARs and loading clips. Karelsen and helpers follow with a heavy machine gun and belt boxes. Warden starts for the porch stairs. He is attracted by something, stops, looks out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lying under an empty bunk with three mattresses piled on He is in his underwear and a helmet, hugs his rifle.
WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll catch a cold, Turp.  THORNHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go out there, First Sergeant! You'll be killed! They're shootin it up! You'll be dead! You'll not be alive any more. Don't go out there!  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better put your pants on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden hits the floor as a plane is heard so loud and low sounds as if it's coming right into the room. A dotted li of bullets crosses the floor and moves into Warden's and Karelsen's room. Warden jumps up and rushes into the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Warden runs in. Broken glass lies all over the floor. Bullet holes are stitched across the top of Warden's footlocker. He throws back the lid fiercely. His linen is polka-dotted with holes. He tosses out shirts, shorts, et digs underneath them. He pulls out a quart bottle of whis it is untouched. Warden smiles with relief. He lifts the bottle to his lips, drinks long and heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About twenty of Company GIs men, including almost all the cams, are on the roof, They are crouched behind the chimn or down on their knees in the corners. The BARs are propp on the low walls or chimney tops, their muzzles pointed t the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three Jap planes, forming a V, are heading straight for camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DHOM (SHOUTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you dirty sons --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scream of the planes drowns Dhom's voice. There is a tremendous clatter as the men fire. The Jap planes pass, untouched. 145.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From this moment on there is no letup of the noise -- the is a wild cacophony of Jap planes, BARs, Karelsen's machi gun, the deep sound of bombs hitting in the far distance. Chief Choate, singing the Regimental marching song, loudl and lustily.  ANOTHER ANGLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Warden comes up on the roof through the skylight. He shouts incoherently at the men. They shout back in a wild cheer. They are like a pack of hungry men enjoying their first big meal in years. In b.g. the Jap V has swung abou and heads back. Warden grabs a BAR from the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: grinning as his plane dives, its guns roaring. His silk s ripples out behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: firing the BAR, standing, as the Jap planes roar over. He staggers back from the recoil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men fire in unison. They rise after the planes pass, shake their fists. Henderson and others of the loading de appear on the roof, bringing up more ammunition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets out a hoarse yell of glee and pride. "These are m boys. This is my Company," it seems to say. The men answe back with a great answering shout.  ANOTHER ANGLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden makes a tour of the roof, laughing, exhorting, slapping the men on their buttocks like a quarterback. Th respond with tremendous spirit; they are having one hell time. We get only a snatch of what Warden is yelling.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Don't worry about wasting ammo! Throw your empty clips down into the yard. The loading detail will pick 'em up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of a bugle blowing insistently is now heard, blending into the rest of the noise. Treadwell runs to th edge of the roof, looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the Bugler's post, Friday Clark is sounding a call.

dialogues.speaker: ROOF
dialogues.text: Treadwell turns, yells at the men. 146.    TREADWELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday's gone crazy! He's blowing the Cavalry Charge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His cheeks puffed, blowing the bugle madly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is lying on a couch in pajamas. He has not shaven, his hair is unkempt. A Radio Announcer is heard over shot. Pr wakens, groggy with hangover and near-delirium, wrestles the blanket over him. CAMERA PULLS BACK to MEDIUM SHOT, DISCLOSING Alma and Gorgette. They have negligees over th nightgowns, are listening to the radio. The Announcer's v tries hard to be calm and official but he cannot keep the tremor out of it. (NOTE: Transcripts of the actual broadc have been requested.)

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ... This is a real attack, not a maneuver. The Japanese are bombing Pearl Harbor. Please keep in your homes. Do not go on the streets. I repeat, this is a real attack. Japanese planes are bombing our naval and army installations. Civilians will remain in their homes. This is a real attack -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Announcer's voice goes on as above.  PREW (MUTTERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, those dirty Germans... Those dirty sneakin Germans...  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Germans?!  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to the radio) Them...  GORGETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Japs. The Japs! 147.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ... Attacks are now taking place at Pearl, Wheeler, Hickam and Schofield...  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... dirty Germans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma shakes Prew, hard. He falls back on the couch, passe out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jap strafing attack is continuing. Their planes are making a figure 8 in the sky. Silhouettes of men on the r can b e seen. Friday Clark is blowing his Cavalry Charge. b.g. men of the loading detail are scurrying around. Lieutenant Ross runs into shot. CAMERA PANS him across th quadrangle toward the barracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Ross is hailed by the loading detail -- about men. He grabs a BAR and ammunition from them and runs int the barracks. The loading detail is working feverishly, s carrying ammunition into the barracks, others picking up empty clips as they are thrown from the roof and hustling them toward the Supply Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is working hard, passing out ammunition to members of loading detail. But he shakes his head dourly as if the w thing is still very unofficial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before, pandemonium -- but controlled and efficient. T men are hoarse from shouting, red-eyed, puffing from excitement and exertion. Two Jap planes swoop past and th full-throated umbrella of fire lets loose. Lieutenant Ros clambers onto the roof, stooping under the burden of the and loading clips. The men greet him with a concerted che

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross looks around the roof, nods with evident approval, c Warden on the shoulder.  DHOM'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound of Jap planes comes up ear-splitting loud. Ross dro down behind a chimney, swings his BAR, fires. CAMERA MOVE INCLUDE Karelsen at the other side of the chimney, firing machine gun. Two soldiers hang onto the bucking legs of t tripod. Two Jap planes pass in b.g. of shot, zoom off int the sky.  KARELSEN (DISGUSTEDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuts! Led him too tar.  MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the men on the roof reload. In the distance the Jap pl have turned and are heading back for the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their lips curled bitterly as their planes head for the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: firing a BAR at the planes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: firing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: firing Joyously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: singing as he fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: firing the machine gun. He yanks the tripod away from his helpers, picks up the gun, stands and swings it after the plane. The recoil staggers him half way across the roof a deposits him on his rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps in his seat like a man tied to a hot stove, thro up his arms helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jap plane bursts into flame and crashes.

dialogues.speaker: ROOF
dialogues.text: The men rise as one with an uproarious cheer. They rush t Karelsen, pick him up. Warden lets go with another of his rebel yells.  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got him, Pete! You got him! 149.    KARELSEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spits over roof) Ah, nobody'll ever know which of us got that guy.  ANOTHER ANGLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the men return to their positions. Two planes head for them, pass over as Company G lets go again with everythin has.  WILSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing after second of THE PLANES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! That last one was one of ours! That was an American plane!  WARDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he ain't got no business here. We're takin care of this sector!  ROSS

dialogues.speaker: SHOT SHOOTING FROM ROOF JAP PLANE
dialogues.text: swooping across the quadrangle about ten feet from the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday Clark, blowing the Cavalry Charge madly, abandons megaphone as he sees the plane coming. He drops on his ch hugging the bugle. The plane passes. Clark jumps up instantly, resumes blowing the Charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same plane has gained altitude so that it is a few fe above the barracks as it heads straight for the roof.  MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men flatten, all but Warden. He stands, swings his BA toward the plane. CAMERA IS ANGLED so that Warden is silhouetted against the sky as he fires at the Jap plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It misses the roof by a foot or two, zooms up at a weird angle. A thick cloud of smoke pours out of the engine. Th plane falls off on one wing and crashes into trees at the of the quadrangle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: crashing. The gas-tank explodes. A cloud of fire and blac 150.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: smoke obscures the screen.  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are improvised blackout curtains over windows and t glass doors. The radio is on, volume low, and an announce (not the one of the morning) is droning out an account of Pearl Harbor. Prew, still on the couch in his pajamas, lo as if he has just struggled to wakefulness. He listens to radio for a few moments in confused disbelief. He shakes head vigorously as if to throw off his grogginess. He sha his head again, slowly, more knowingly now, nodding as if remembers something from the broadcast of the morning. Th as if all of it hits him suddenly and fully and terribly wrenches himself off the couch. He looks around at the di lit room.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma! Alma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the blackout curtains, peeps out. Then he turn back to listen to the radio. Abruptly, he runs into the bedroom.  PREW'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room remains empty for a few moments as the radio announcer goes on, continuing previous remarks.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: -- ready to fight and die for us, our Regular Army and Navy have this day upheld the faith and confidence we have always placed in them. They have proved their right to the esteem we have always had for them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew comes back into the room. He has his shoes on, holds civilian shirt and pants in his hand. He starts to put th on hurriedly, his attention still focused on the broadcas The front door opens and Alma and Gorgette enter. They ar surprised to see Prew up. He nods at them, turns back qui to listen to the radio as he continues dressing.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ... the attack caused serious damage to many installations of which Pearl Harbor suffered the worst. (MORE)
RADIO ANNOUNCER'S VOICE(cont'd) We will not forget this day -- and we will never let the Japanese forget it...  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells at radio) You said it! Who they think they're fight in? (incoherent with rage; to GIRLS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're pickin trouble with the best Army in -- the best riflemen -- you know we the ony country on the face of the earth that uses the shooting gunsling, not the carrying gunsling. You know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio continues on under the scene. Alma and Gorgette speak breathlessly, in a rush.  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been at Queens Hospital -- giving blood --  GORGETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town's a madhouse. Trucks, busses, jeeps all over --  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A house on Kuhio Street was bombed OUT --  GORGETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the drugstore on McKully and King is smashed flat. And the man and his wife were killed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew gestures to radio as if he's heard all about it. He sticks his shirttails into his trousers.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get back to the Post -- I'll try to get in touch with you in a couple days --  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Post? Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew nods vehemently, moves across room to a table.  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why? 152.    PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? There's a war goin on.  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can't! You're not fit yet -- you're weak as a kitten -- you're AWOL -- they'll throw you in the STOCKADE --  PREP (LAUGHS WILDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be throwin `em out of the Stockade. They need every man they can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the sheet of paper with the "Re-enlistment Bl written out on it, starts to fold it. Desperation is reflected on Alma's face; she turns to Gorgette, as if pleading for aid,  GORGETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your side'll open up --  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they'll find out it was you who killed that soldier!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew shakes his head, as if obsessed by only one thought.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once I report in to the Compny I'll be all right. Once I get there. I gotta get back --  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you'll never make it! There's MPs all over --  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make it. I'll go along the back roads. They'll let me in the West gate -- they'll know I'm a SOLJER --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the folded piece of paper in his pocket and start for the door.  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay till morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew glances at Alma incredulously. She sobs suddenly, violently. 153.    ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if you stayed till morning you'd change your mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws her arms around him, clings to him.  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go, Prew! I'll do whatever you want... We'll figure out a way to get to the States together... We can even get married... If you go I won't see you any more... I know it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew holds her closely for a moment, then moves her away him. He turns toward the door.  ALMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tears turning to HYSTERIA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to go back to the Army for?! What did the Army ever do for you? Besides treat you like scum and give you one awful going over and get your friend killed? What do you want to go back to that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prew frowns as if he's not sure he heard correctly.  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I want to go back for? I'm a soljer.  ALMA (LAUGHING WILDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A soldier! A soldier! A Regular. From the Regular Army. A thirty- year man!  PREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. A thirty-year man. (GRINS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With only twenty-six years to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door quickly and slips into the darkness.  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING SHOT JEEP WITH THREE MPs The night is inky black except for a little moonlight and 154.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: dimmed headlights of the jeep. CAMERA SHOOTS PAST driver the highway as the jeep moves slowly along. The two other clutch Thompson guns, try to scan the dark countryside.  FIRST MP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say they seen parachutists land up in the mountains.  SECOND MP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't worried about them. Sabatoors is what worries me.  DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Theys the creepy ones. Walkin around just like ordinary civilians. I betcha they operatin all over these islands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
